Ken

I sent Cesar the first version of my python neat
stuff.  If you still have any of the later versions
with checkpoint/restart, etc feel free to release it
or sent it to Cesar.  I haven't found the laptop I was
using back then yet to see if it still has the more
recent versions.


--- cchtty37 <cchtty37@...> wrote:

> Ken/Cesar,
> 
> I have been working on my own version of NEAT in
> Python, but it is
> still in a fairly primitive state (many bugs and
> some of the more
> recent features of NEAT have not been implemented).
> You are more than
> welcome to take a look, though:
> http://code.google.com/p/pyneat/
> 
> Please let me know if you have any feedback.
> 
> Thanks,
> Brian
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley"
> <kstanley@...> wrote:
> >
> > Cesar, I agree it would be nice to make python
> NEAT available on the 
> > website.  I believe I asked Karl Lewin for
> permission to do that 
> > about three years ago, but he told me the code
> wasn't in suitable 
> > condition to be released.  Since then, we seem to
> have lost touch.  
> > You are correct that he is the one who produced a
> python NEAT version.
> > 
> > I think I remember others mentioning they were
> working on Python 
> > versions of NEAT but I can't remember who it was. 
> If someone has 
> > such a version and wants to make it available, I
> will be happy to 
> > link it from my website.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Cesar G. Miguel"
> <cesargm@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hello NEAT users,
> > > 
> > > I know there's a python version of NEAT not
> listed in Ken's website.
> > > Searching for 'python' on the group's history I
> found some threads
> > > about it from 2004-2005. I contacted the author
> (Karl Lewin) and the
> > > guy (Thomas) who was asking for the source code,
> but received no
> > > replies (I'm not even sure they use the same
> e-mail).
> > > 
> > > Web archive last Karl's website record is from
> 2005, but the source
> > > file (pyn.zip) is not available.
> > > 
> > > Does anyone have the code or is it lost forever?
> > > 
> > > @Ken, wouldn't it be nice to list the python
> version on the website
> > > (given Karl's permission)?
> > > 
> > > Thanks,
> > > Cesar
> > >
> >
> 
> 
>
